keyTakeAways: The Ostwall, a Nazi-built underground city in Poland, is now a dark tourism site open to visitors via the Międzyrzecz Fortified Region Museum.
The Passage of Commodus, a Roman tunnel in Italy, is being opened to the public and is linked to a historical assassination attempt on Emperor Commodus.
The London Tunnels, once used by Britain’s Special Operations Executive, are set to become a major tourist attraction after a $149 million renovation.
Kayaköy, a Turkish ghost town, is a haunting reminder of the Greco-Turkish war and is visited by tourists paying a small fee.
Babylon’s ruins in Iraq remain a significant historical site despite being overgrown and under-resourced.
The Trans-Allegheny Lunatic Asylum in West Virginia is now a tourist attraction that offers a blend of history and paranormal experiences.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article explores various underground and abandoned sites around the world, highlighting their historical significance and transformation into tourist attractions. Central to the piece is the Ostwall, a massive Nazi-built underground city in Poland abandoned in 1945, now open to visitors as a dark tourism destination. It also features the Roman Passage of Commodus, where Emperor Commodus may have survived an assassination attempt. A Cold War-era network of tunnels in London is undergoing a $149 million renovation to become a major tourist site. Additional stories include the ghost town of Kayaköy in Turkey, ancient Babylon in Iraq, and the Trans-Allegheny Lunatic Asylum in West Virginia, which now offers tours blending history and paranormal legends. These examples illustrate how remnants of war, empire, and societal collapse are being reinterpreted for public fascination.
title: Deep underground, the Nazis built a city for thousands of soldiers. Now it’s a tourist attraction
